Let $f(x)\in \mathbb{R}[x]$ be a polynomial of degree $n$ whose roots $\{a_0<\cdots<a_n\}$ are all real and form an arithmetic progression.

The differences between consecutive zeros of $f'(x)$, beginning from the midpoint of $(a_0,a_m)$ towards the endpoints, are monotonically increasing.



All the zeros of $f'(x)$ are all distinct real numbers in $(a_0,a_m)$ by Rolle's theorem.

This was proved by Balint \cite{Ba60b}. Balint gives no source for the conjecture - presumably it was from Erd\H{o}s in personal communication. Some generalisations of this were given by Lorch \cite{Lo76}.




References


[Ba60b] B\'alint, Elem\'{e}r, Proof of a conjecture of {P}. {E}rd\H{o}s. Mat. Lapok (1960), 33--40.

[Lo76] Lorch, L., Some monotonicity properties of polynomials with equally
spaced zeros. Acta Math. Acad. Sci. Hungar. (1976), 293--300.
